Tic-Tac-Toe

Created a tic-tac-toe game for 2 players

I coded up The game of Tic Tac Toe which is played on a 3x3 grid in C++ and Python. First the grid is initially empty. Two players take turns, one playing as ‘X’ and the other as ‘O’. The goal of the game is to get three of your symbols in a row, either horizontally, vertically, or diagonally. At the start of the game, the empty grid is displayed. Each cell of the grid is represented by a number from 1 to 9. Players take turns choosing a number that corresponds to a cell they want to place their symbol in. After each move, the grid is updated and displayed again. The players continue taking turns until one of them manages to get three of their symbols in a row or if the entire grid is filled without a winner, resulting in a draw. To win, a player must have three of their symbols in a horizontal, vertical, or diagonal line. If a player achieves this, the game ends and they are declared the winner. If all the cells are filled and no player has won, the game is declared a draw. The game can be played by two human players or a human player against an AI opponent. The AI opponent can be programmed to make intelligent moves using strategies such as looking for winning moves or blocking the opponent from winning. The players can play multiple rounds of Tic Tac Toe, keeping track of their wins and draws. The game continues until the players decide to quit.

Visit Tic-Tac-Toe Code

  • Project: Personal
  • Category: Python

Hangman

Created a C++ game called hangman project for my CSCI 135 class

Using C++, the Hangman game was crafted by employing fundamental programming concepts such as loops, conditionals, and arrays to manage word selection, player input, and visual representation of the hangman's progress. The game logic was structured around comparing user guesses with the target word, updating the display with each correct guess, while also limiting incorrect attempts to eventually reveal the full hangman illustration.

Visit Hangman Code

  • Project: School
  • Category: C++

Esteelauder Project

Made a website within a day with what we had learned with Kode With Klossy for the past two weeks.

In just one day, I utilized the skills imparted by Kode With Klossy to craft a compelling website for Estée Lauder. Armed with the fundamentals of HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, I embraced responsive design principles to ensure the website's compatibility across devices. The problem-solving mindset cultivated by Kode With Klossy proved invaluable as I swiftly addressed challenges, resulting in a polished website that showcased Estée Lauder's offerings with elegance and interactivity.

Emotion-Detector

Unlocking the Power of AI: Building a Real-time Emotion Reader with DeepFace and Python

A month ago, I embarked on a journey to explore the fascinating world of AI and its applications. I was curious to learn more about how AI can calculate someone's gender, age, and facial expression quickly transformed into a passionate learning experience. The journey wasn't without its hurdles. Understanding the nuances of facial detection, deciphering the technical jargon, and fine-tuning the DeepFace parameters presented unique challenges. But with each hurdle cleared, my understanding grew, and my code evolved. Days turned into weeks as I learned more about open source and the endless opportunity to improve my code and project. Finally, after a month of dedication and exploration, I achieved my goal. My Python script, powered by DeepFace, could now analyze a face in real-time, estimating the person's age, gender, and even their dominant emotion! The satisfaction of turning my initial curiosity into a tangible skill was immense. This project allowed me to gain practical knowledge in AI and facial recognition and instilled a valuable lesson: with dedication and the right tools, even seemingly complex tasks can be tackled and mastered.

Visit My Code

  • Project: Emotion-Detector
  • Category: Open Source: DeepFace, Python
